entry.content:
• ç›®å‰ä¸»è¦å¬bbc 6min new review/çœ‹æ–°é—»

time:2024.2.4 DAY1

  • ä»2024.1.21å¼€å§‹ï¼ˆä»¥å‰å¬äº†12å¤©ï¼‰ï¼Œåˆ°ä»Šå¤©2024.2.4éƒ½æ²¡å¬åªæ˜¯æ¯å¤©çœ‹è–„è·é˜…è¯»

Key words and phrases:

ğŸ” history in the making - an event that will be remembered as really significant

  • Sending astronauts to the Moon was history in the making.
  • The election of the first female US president will be history in the making.

ğŸ” off the menu - not an option

  • We havenâ€™t got any bread at home, so sandwiches are off the menu.
  • A holiday is off the menu this month because Iâ€™ve got too many work deadlines.

ğŸ” overjoyed - very happy

  • She was overjoyed to receive the acceptance letter from her dream university.
  • The parents were overjoyed to see their son taking his first steps.

âœ”ï¸ 0:00 - Introduction
âœ”ï¸ 0:24 - Story
âœ”ï¸ 1:15 - Headline 1
âœ”ï¸ 2:47 - Headline 2
âœ”ï¸ 4:28 - Headline 3
âœ”ï¸ 5:48 - Language summary

DAY2 2024.2.5

Killer

  • a cause of death / something difficult or unpleasant
    • â€œIâ€™ve told you to stop smoking! Cigarettes are a killer!â€
    • â€œRunning the marathon was a killer, but I did it!â€

Detrimental

  • likely to cause harm
    • â€œStudies have found that air pollution can be detrimental to our health.â€
    • â€œVinh prioritises his work, to the detriment of his family relationships.â€

Burden

  • something that causes hard work or difficulty
    • â€œA criminal record is a burden that no young person wants to carry.â€
    • â€œPlease donâ€™t burden me with any more of your problems. Iâ€™ve had enough!â€

DAY3 2024.2.13ï¼ˆè¿ç»­ç¬¬ä¸€å¤©ï¼‰

erupts
expresses something suddenly and with force

  • Violence erupted at the political rally last weekend.
  • Villagers were evacuated when the volcano threatened to erupt.

shoulders blame
accepts responsibility

  • Children should not have to shoulder the blame for their parentsâ€™ mistakes.
  • This is your mistake. Donâ€™t expect me to shoulder the blame for you!

broke into
entered without permission

  • Thieves broke into the museum late last night.
  • Hackers have caused damage after breaking into the bankâ€™s computer system.

DAY4 2024.2.14ï¼ˆè¿ç»­ç¬¬2å¤©ï¼‰

Key words and phrases:

ramp up
increase level of something dramatically

  • The company decided to ramp up production of the new phone after high demand.
  • After being told his work wasnâ€™t good enough, Clive decided to ramp up his efforts.

formidable
describes something that causes fear because it is difficult

  • Marcela faced formidable challenges to get her project funded after the financial crash.
  • The politician was forced to resign after her formidable opponent accused her of lying.

explodes
increases rapidly

  • The number of people working from home exploded during the pandemic.
  • Sales exploded after the celebrity was seen using the new phone.

Monkeypox: New disease spreads: BBC News Review - YouTube

2024.2.15 day5(actully day3)

ğŸ” **pick up the slack** - do work that someone else hasn't done - *Tony left suddenly, we're all going to have to pick up the slack.* - *Sorry I had to leave early. Thanks for picking up the slack.*

ğŸ” drive the trend - make a pattern happen

  • The hot weather has driven the trend for gourmet ice cream.
  • Environmental concerns have driven the trend for plant-based food.

ğŸ” put in - spend

  • If you put in the hours, youâ€™ll get promoted.
  • My aunt put a lot of money into my company.
  • https://youtu.be/l5qMesQWSCE?si=RvL6xb_nrORvtN0D

2024.2.16 day6(actully day4)

Key Words and Phrases:

ğŸ” meaty

  • Definition: interesting, complex, or thought-provoking.
  • Example 1: â€œYouâ€™ll be able to write a lot about this â€“ itâ€™s a meaty topic.â€
  • Example 2: â€œIâ€™m reading classical literature at the moment â€“ I like to read meaty books.â€

ğŸ” salvo

  • Definition: an attack or criticism.
  • Example 1: â€œHis criticism was just the opening salvo in the attack on his colleagues.â€
  • Example 2: â€œThe new laws are just the first salvo in attempts to stop dangerous driving.â€

ğŸ” reignite

  • Definition: start up again.
  • Example 1: â€œThe quality of films released this year has reignited my passion for cinema.â€
  • Example 2: â€œThe ministerâ€™s speech reignited bad feelings with her rivals.â€

neal and betty æ˜¯æˆ‘æœ€å–œæ¬¢çœ‹çš„ä¸»æ’­å“ˆå“ˆå“ˆå“ˆå¤©å¤©æ‰¾ä»–ä»¬ä¸¤ä¸ªåˆä½œçš„è§†é¢‘ã€‚

2024.2.17 day7(actully day5)

Key words and phrases:
âœ”ï¸ purging - removing something that you donâ€™t want

  • We will purge corruption from this organisation.
  • The new leader purged his opponentâ€™s supporters from the party.

âœ”ï¸ citing - giving as the reason for something

  • More people are leaving their jobs citing stress.
  • Make sure you cite any research you mention.

âœ”ï¸ overstretching - getting something to do too much

  • Iâ€™m going to stop now. I donâ€™t want to overstretch myself.
  • Weâ€™ve overstretched our budget â€“ we have no money.

2024.2.18 day8 (actually day6)

Taiwan election angers China: BBC News Review

Video Link: https://youtu.be/1MWX-3ZqcMk?si=fPR3GV7yq4q_E-JC

Key words and phrases:

ğŸ” status quo - the way things are

  • Employees should challenge the status quo if they want their company to change.
  • Some people love change, whereas others prefer sticking to the status quo.

ğŸ” fumes - expresses extreme anger or frustration

  • After some negative feedback, he left the room fuming with anger.
  • He called customer services and fumed over the failed delivery.

ğŸ” rock solid - very strong or unlikely to change

  • Their relationship was rock solid once they had repaired the trust.
  • After years of hard work, her professional reputation was rock solid.

2024.2.19 day9 (actually day7)

**Key words and phrases:**

ğŸ” implant - something placed inside your body

  • The cochlear implants allowed her to hear again.
  • A pacemaker is a type of heart implant.

ğŸ” interface - a connection between two systems

  • This programâ€™s user interface is really complicated.
  • The film explores the interface between dreams and reality.

ğŸ” cyborg - part-human, part-machine

  • The cyborg in the film has a mechanical arm.
  • The cyborg-like beetle can be controlled by scientists.

2024.2.19 day10 (actually day8)

**Key words and phrases:**

ğŸ” looms - something worrying is coming soon

  • The team is working hard to finish the project as the deadline looms.
  • A health crisis looms with the rapid spread of a new virus.

ğŸ” hangs by a thread - is in danger of failing

  • After the injury, the athleteâ€™s chances of winning the race now hang by a thread.
  • Hope for peace in the region hangs by a thread as war continues.

ğŸ” baffled - extremely confused

  • Despite hours of studying, she was still baffled.
  • The sudden disappearance of the key left him absolutely baffled.

2024.2.25 day11 (æˆ‘å±…ç„¶å…­å¤©æ²¡å¬å¬åŠ›å¯æ€•!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

https://youtu.be/FZDImEiPgMk?si=-kSM47QSuHpscjD9

Feed your brain â²ï¸ 6 Minute English

2024.2.27 day12

ğŸ‘‰**Key words and phrases:**

ğŸ”keep (something) at bay
prevent something bad affecting you

  • Hand washing can keep infections at bay.
  • New economic policies are needed to keep inflation at bay.

ğŸ”stave off
prevent something bad affecting you

  • Orange juice staves off colds.
  • Joining social clubs can stave off loneliness.

ğŸ”drive
force in a certain direction

  • Greenhouse gases drive climate change.
  • Bad pay drives teachers to quit their profession.

2024.2.28 day13

ğŸ” well-off - rich

  • They own two houses and three cars. Theyâ€™re quite well-off.
  • Some people think that the most well-off should pay the highest taxes.

ğŸ” plundering - taking what doesnâ€™t belong to you

  • The thieves plundered the shop and took thousands of poundsâ€™ worth of jewellery.
  • Citizens plunder for food and fuel in desperation.

ğŸ” clean up their acts - improve their behaviour

  • You need to clean up your act if you want to get into a good university.
  • She parties too much. She needs to clean up her act

2024.2.29 day14

ğŸ‘‰ Key words and phrases:

ğŸ” repelled - forced away

  • My new jacket repels water â€“ itâ€™s waterproof.
  • Some animals have spiky skin that repels predators.

ğŸ” high-stakes - high risk

  • IELTS is a high-stakes test. Youâ€™ll have to pay to do it again if you fail.
  • I played poker last night. It was a high-stakes game with a lot of money at risk.

ğŸ” running rife - uncontrolled

  • The kids ran rife at the party. They were out of control.
  • Criminals run rife in this area. Be careful.

hhhhhhh

2024.3.5 day15ï¼ˆå››å¤©æ²¡æœ‰å¬ï¼ï¼ï¼ï¼ï¼ï¼ï¼ï¼ï¼ï¼‰

  • ğŸ‘‰Key words and phrases:

  • drought

    ğŸ” period of time with no rain - Drought can cause dangerous wildfires to start. - The country had to import food after a drought made crops fail.

  • overwhelm

ğŸ” cover something completely and quickly -The city was overwhelmed by water after the river burst its banks. -Tourists overwhelm city centres during the summer holiday.

  • taints

ğŸ” makes something good turn bad -The lake was tainted by industrial waste. -His reputation was tainted after he was caught stealing money from his company.

2024.3.6 day16

ğŸ‘‰ Key words and phrases:
ğŸ” use up - use all of something

  • Why did you use up all the milk? I need some for my coffee.
  • I used up most of my brain power studying for that science test!

ğŸ” (not) in (easy) reach - not close or achievable

  • The end of the school term is in reach. Just one last exam!
  • Because of her injury, the Olympics are not in easy reach now.

ğŸ” pour cold water on - be negative about something

  • His mum poured cold water on the idea of having a house party.
  • You canâ€™t cheat! Iâ€™m pouring cold water on that immediately.

2024.3.7 day17

ğŸ” enshrines - protects in law
â€¢ The right to free speech has been enshrined in the countryâ€™s constitution.
â€¢ The idea that education should be free has now been enshrined in law.

ğŸ” lament - express sadness
â€¢ Health campaigners lamented the increase in junk food advertising.
â€¢ The manager lamented the teamâ€™s missed chances.

ğŸ” follow its lead - go in the same direction
â€¢ We just found a successful company and followed its lead.
â€¢ Dancing is easy. Just follow my lead

2024.3.9 day18ï¼ˆä¸€å¤©æ²¡å¬è¯¥æ­»ï¼‰

ğŸ” trickle - a small amount which can increase

  • Charity workers were disappointed when only a trickle of aid arrived.
  • There will only be a trickle of new content during the writersâ€™ strikes.

ğŸ” captives - trapped people or animals

  • There were hundreds of captives after the battle.
  • The workers became captives after the mine collapsed.

ğŸ” tipping point - a critical time when things might suddenly become much worse

  • Inflation is at a tipping point. People canâ€™t afford the basics.
  • The failed ceasefire could be a tipping point in the war

2024.3.10 day 19

ğŸ‘‰Key words and phrases:

ğŸ” having a laugh

  • enjoying yourself; joking
  • Example: Come out tonight! Weâ€™ll have a laugh!
  • Example: Are you serious or just having a laugh?

ğŸ” literally

  • using the real meaning of a word
  • Example: We received literally thousands of applications.
  • Example: Excitement is building as we are literally seconds away from kick-off

ğŸ” first-of-its-kind

  • different to anything before
  • Example: This is the worldâ€™s oldest car â€“ itâ€™s the first of its kind.
  • Example: The film was the first of its kind. No-one had made one like that before.

2024.3.11 day20

ğŸ” ordeal - very unpleasant experience

  • Escaping the warzone was an ordeal Iâ€™ll never forget.
  • Exams are an ordeal, but you need to take them!

ğŸ” nail-biting - describes a worrying or stressful situation

  • Waiting for the test results was nail-biting.
  • Penalty shoot-outs are sportâ€™s most nail-biting experience.

ğŸ” makeshift - temporary and low quality

  • The refugees were housed in makeshift accommodation.
  • There were a number of makeshift classrooms in the school after it was damaged.

2024.3.12day21

ğŸ” kicking habits

  • stopping habits
    • Iâ€™m trying to stop eating chocolate, but I havenâ€™t kicked the habit yet.
    • I want to kick the habit of checking my phone all the time.

ğŸ” longevity

  • living or lasting a long time
    • The study found that regular exercise improves longevity.
    • Having friendly colleagues and flexible hours helps create longevity in a job.

ğŸ” adopting

  • taking as your own
    • The organization has adopted a new approach to hiring.
    • After watching that documentary, many have adopted a new attitude towards eating meat.
